awd_titl_txt: AMPS: Collaborative Research: Efficient Algorithms for Ultra-Fast Detection of Power System Contingencies in the Transient Regime
awd_abstract_narration:
The stability of the electric power system is of the utmost importance for its reliable operation. This work focuses on the impact of large disturbances, such as the loss of a transmission line due to a short-circuit, or the sudden disconnection of a thermal generating unit due to an unpredictable malfunction. When such faults occur, the system undergoes a transient event of highly nonlinear nature.  The ongoing large-scale integration of renewable energy resources in the grid challenges conventional transient stability analysis, and reduces the 'inertia' of the system. At the same time, there is a proliferation of phasor measurement units (PMUs) on the grid. These sensors provide accurate, high-frequency information about voltage, current, and frequency at various locations around the system, and are instrumental in increasing our system-level situation awareness. Nevertheless, the transformation of the incoming data to actionable information is still an open research problem. In the context of transient regimes, it is important to establish as soon as possible, i.e., within a few electrical cycles, what has gone wrong, in order to predict the evolution of the system dynamics over the period of time following the fault. Such 'ultra-fast' detection is critical, since it may allow appropriate actions to be taken by a wide-area monitoring and control system that can actuate various assets around the grid, such as flexible ac transmission system (FACTS) devices or even the converters of renewable resources.

The main objective of this work is to develop computationally scalable, yet statistically efficient, real-time algorithms in order to detect and identify contingencies in the early stages of the transient regime of the power system based on PMU outputs. The validity and efficacy of these algorithms will be based on a stochastic model for the power system during the transient stability regime following a contingency.  This is a very challenging problem that cannot be addressed with existing uncertainty propagation methodologies, because of the high-dimensionality and the computational complexity of the power grid dynamical system. A key component is the reformulation of the uncertainty propagation problem which overcomes the curse of dimensionality, enables the fast re-estimation of the statistics as the power system operating point changes, and allows for the adaptive selection of power system simulations.  This work will rely on combination of diverse techniques, such as uncertainty quantification, power grid modeling, and sequential detection.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Situational awareness is essential for the reliable and secure operation of power systems. This term includes an array of technologies that provide precise information over time, including actions taken to restore or maintain normal operation. Due to the highly interconnected nature of modern power networks, transmission system operators (TSO) must also be aware of the state of neighboring systems that may affect the reliability of their control area. Poor situational awareness and lack of information sharing across TSO boundaries have been significant contributing factors in several recent blackouts across the United States and Europe. Recent advancements in power system measurement and monitoring technology, such as the proliferation of phasor measurement units (PMU), provide new opportunities for improving situational awareness in power systems.

Driven by these opportunities, in this project we developed a versatile and robust method for the real-time detection and isolation of transmission line outages using high-frequency PMU data. Unlike previous approaches that rely on the modeling of the quasi steady-state behavior, a key novelty of our approach is that we use high-fidelity models for the transient regime to build the detection and isolation algorithm. Moreover, our approach allows for the available sensors to be sparsely placed and far from the location of the outage. As a result, it can help provide precise and timely information across transmission system operators regarding the current system state and its anticipated evolution over time. Thus, this methodology has the potential to contribute to better information sharing across and improved situational awareness of the power system.

Motivated by the above problem, in this grant we also revisited the generic problem of joint sequential change detection and identification, also known as sequential change diagnosis. Specifically, the problem is to detect as quickly as possible, in real time, a disruption in the monitored system, e.g., a power system contingency, and at the same to accurately determine its type, direction, or location. We highlighted certain drawbacks of existing algorithms, revised state-of-the-art results in this literature, introduced a comprehensive, practical method for comparing change diagnosis procedures, and proposed a novel algorithm that resolves the above issues, while preserving the advantages of existing algorithms. These methodological and theoretical results can have an impact on the ubiquitous applications of the sequential change diagnosis problem, which include but are not limited to the detection and isolation of contingencies in power systems.
